headline: President Trump defends response to COVID crisis in exclusive interview with Chris Wallace

utterances.speaker: CHRIS WALLACE, FOX NEWS ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: I'm Chris Wallace. In the middle of a pandemic, an election year, and a nation divided, we talk in depth with President Donald Trump.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Today, we spend the full hour at the White House and asked the president about the nation's most pressing issues.  Let's start with a surge of the coronavirus across the country in recent months. A lot of people say this is because we don't have a national plan. Do you take responsibility for that?  We ask him about reopening schools and whether Washington will pass another big relief bill for businesses that have been shut down and workers that have been laid off. The stimulus bill is running out the end of this month. Will you only sign a bill that has those two provisions?  Then, the nationwide protests against racism and police forces, along with a dramatic increase in urban violence.   There has been a spike in violent crime in America in recent weeks. How do you explain it and what are you going to do about it? And we tell the president about new FOX polls from the state of the 2020 race. You talked about how you're winning and campaign is going well, why did you replace Brad Parscale?   And much more about Dr. Fauci and the cancel culture, and Mary Trump's tell-all book.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.sentences: Didn't have a lot of respect or like for her. I would have never said that except she writes a book that is so stupid and so vicious and it's a lie.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: In our one-on-one exclusive with Donald Trump.  All, right now, on "FOX News Sunday."

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And hello again from Fox News in Washington. Today from the White House, we're on the president's patio just outside the Oval Office.  President Trump, you've agreed to answer all manner of questions, no subject off-limits. Thank you and welcome back to FOX NEWS SUNDAY.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Let's start with the surge of the coronavirus across the country in recent months. You still talk about it as, quote, "burning embers." But I want to put up a chart that shows where we are with the illness over the last four months.  As you can see, we hit a peak here in April, 36,000 cases --

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Cases.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: -- a day.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Yes, cases.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Then -- then it went down and now since June it has gone up more than double. One day this week 75,000 new cases. More than double --

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Chris, that's because we have great testing, because we have the best testing in the world. If we didn't test, you wouldn't be able to show that chart. If we tested half as much, those numbers would be down.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: But -- but this isn't burning embers, sir? This is a firestorm.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: No, no. But I don't say -- I say flames, we'll put out the flames. And we'll put out in some cases just burning embers. We also have burning embers. We have embers and we do have flames. Florida became more flame- like, but it's -- it's going to be under control. And, you know, it's not just this country, it's many countries. We don't talk about it in the news. They don't talk about Mexico and Brazil and still parts of Europe, which actually got hit sooner than us, so it's a little ahead of us in that sense.   But you take a look, why don't they talk about Mexico? Which is not helping us. And all I can say is thank God I built most of the wall, because if I didn't have the wall up we would have a much bigger problem with Mexico.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: But, sir, we have the seventh highest mortality rate in the world. Our mortality rate is higher than Brazil, it's higher than Russia and the European Union has us on a travel ban.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Yeah. I think what we'll do -- well, we have them under travel ban, too, Chris. I closed them off. If you remember, I was the one that did the European Union very early.  But when you talk about mortality risks, I think it's the opposite. I think we have one of the lowest mortality rates in the world.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: It's not true, sir. We had -- we had 900 deaths on a single day - -

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: We will take a look --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: -- just this week --

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Ready?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Can you please get me the mortality rates?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Kayleigh's right here. I heard we have one of the lowest, maybe the lowest mortality rate anywhere in the world.   Do you have the numbers, please? Because I heard we had the best mortality rate.

utterances.speaker: KAYLEIGH MCENANY, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE) Dr. Birx points out and this is --

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Number one low mortality fatality rates. I hope you show the scenario because it shows what fake news is all about - -

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: OK, OK. I don't think I'm fake news but I will -- we'll put --

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Yeah, you are --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: -- put our staff on --

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: You said we had the worst mortality rate in the world --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I said you had --

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: -- and we have the best.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Look, I take responsibility always for everything because it's ultimately my job too. I have to get everybody in line.  Some governors have done well, some governors have done poorly. They're supposed to have supplies they didn't have; I supplied everybody. Now we have somewhat of a surge in certain areas and other areas we're doing great. But we have a surge in certain areas. But you don't hear people complaining about ventilators. We've got all the ventilators we can use; we're supplying them to other countries. We go out into parking lots and everything, everybody gets a test. We find -- if we did half the testing -- with all of that being said, I'm glad we did it. This is the right way to do it. I'm glad we did what we're doing, but we have more tests by far than any country in the world.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: But, sir, testing is up 37 percent.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Well, that's good.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I understand. Cases are up 194 percent. It isn't just that testing has gone up, it's that the virus has spread. The positivity rate has increased. There --

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Many of those cases --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: -- than it was.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Many of those cases are young people that would heal in a day. They have the sniffles and we put it down as a test. Many of them -- don't forget, I guess it's like 99.7 percent, people are going to get better and many cases, they're going to get better very quickly. If we go out and we look and then on the news -- look if you go back to the news, all of your -- even your wonderful competitors, you'll see cases are up. Well, cases are up -- many of those cases shouldn't even be cases. Cases are up because we have the best testing in the world and we have the most testing.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: No country has ever done what we've done in terms of testing. We are the envy of the world. They call and they say the most incredible job anybody's done is our job on testing, because we're going to very shortly be up to 50 million tests. You look at other countries, they don't even do tests. They do tests if somebody walks into the hospital, they're sick, they're really sick, they test them then, or they'll test them in a doctor's office. But they don't go around have massive areas of testing and we do. And I'm glad we do, but it really skews the numbers.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I'm going to do you a favor, because I'm sure a lot of people listening right now are going to say, "Trump, he tries to play it down, he tries to make it not being as serious as it is."

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I don't play it -- I'm not playing -- no, this is very serious.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Seventy-five thousand cases a day.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Show me the death chart.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Well, I don't have the death chart.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Well, the death chart is much more important.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: But I can tell you, the death chart is a thousand cases a day.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Excuse me, it's all too much, it shouldn't be one case. It came from China. They should've never let it escape, they should've never let it out, but it is what it is. Take a look at Europe. Take a look at the numbers in Europe. And by the way, they're having surges (ph).

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: (inaudible) cases are 6,000 in the whole European Union.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: They don't test. They don't test.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Is it possible that they don't have the virus as badly as we do?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: It's possible that they don't test, that's what's possible. We find cases and many of those cases heal automatically. We're finding -- in a way, we're creating trouble. Certainly, we are creating trouble for the fake news to come along and say, "Oh, we have more cases." Look, we did something that nobody's ever done. Not only the ventilators, where we're supplying them all over the world. We did a testing program the likes of which nobody's ever done before.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: The head of the CDC, Dr. Redfield, said this on Tuesday.

utterances.speaker: DR. ROBERT REDFIELD, CDC DIRECTOR
utterances.sentences: I think this fall and winter will probably be one of the most difficult times we face in public health.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Do you agree with Dr. Redfield?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I don't know and I don't think he knows. I don't think anybody knows with this. This is a very tricky deal. Everybody thought this summer it would go away and it would come back in the fall. Well, when the summer came, they used to say the heat -- the heat was good for it and it really knocked it out, remember? And then it might come back in the fall. So they got that one wrong. They -- they got a lot wrong. They got a lot wrong. The World Health got a tremendous amount wrong. They basically did whatever China wanted them to. And we'll save now almost $500 million a year, which is nice. But the World Health got a lot wrong.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: This is one of the sharpest criticisms of you.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I agree.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: People say that you talk about the world as you'd like to see it rather than follow the science.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Let me just ask the question, sir. Why on earth would your administration be involved in a campaign at this point to discredit Dr. Fauci, who is the nation's top infectious disease expert?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Because we're not. If one man from my administration doesn't like him because he made a few mistakes -- look, Dr. Fauci said, "Don't wear a mask." Dr. Fauci told me not to ban China, it would be a big mistake. I did it over and above his reservation. Dr. Fauci then said, "You saved tens of thousands of lives" -- more than that. He said, "You saved tens of thousands of lives." Dr. Fauci's made some mistakes, but I have a very good -- I spoke to him yesterday at length. I have a very good relationship with Dr. Fauci.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: But -- but, sir, this week -- this weekend, your White House put out a series of statements, so-called mistakes that Dr. Fauci had made. One of your right-hand men, Daniel Scavino, put out -- you've seen this? Dr. -- Dr. Faucet, which shows him as a leaker and an alarmist. Why would --

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Well, I don't know (inaudible) he's a little bit of an alarmist. That's OK. A little bit of an --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: He's a bit of an alarmist?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Dr. Fauci at the beginning said this will pass, don't worry about it, this will pass, he was wrong. Dr. Fauci said don't ban China, I did, he then admitted that I was right.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: But you made mistakes too.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I guess everybody makes mistakes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I was going to say, you said at one point...

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: One person coming in from China and we have it under control. It's going to be just fine. When you have 15 people in the 15 within a couple of days is going to be down to close to zero, that's a pretty good job we've done. I think we are going to be very good with the coronavirus. I think that at some point that's going to sort of just disappear.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I'll be right eventually. I will be right eventually. You know I said, "It's going to disappear." I'll say it again. It's going to disappear and I'll be right.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: (inaudible).

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I don't think so. I don't think so. You know why (inaudible)? Because I've been right probably more than anybody else.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Then there were masks. From the first day that the CDC said that people should wear masks on April 3rd, you said you weren't going to. You wore a mask for the first time in public -

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: - at Walter Reed this weekend. Question, the CDC says if everybody wore a mask for 4-6 weeks, we could get this under control. Do you regret not wearing a mask in a public from the start, and would you consider - will you consider a national mandate that people need to wear masks?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: No I want people to have a certain freedom, and I don't believe in that. No, and I don't agree with the statement that if everybody wear a mask everything disappears. Hey, Dr. Fauci said don't wear a mask. Our Surgeon General -- terrific guy -- said don't wear a mask. Everybody who is saying don't wear a mask -- all of sudden everybody's got to wear a mask, and as you know masks cause problems, too. With that being said, I'm a believer in masks. I think masks are good. But I leave it up to the governors. Many of the governors are changing. They're more mask into -- they like the concept of masks, but some of them don't agree. I do say this -- schools have to open. Young people have to go to school, and there's problems when you don't go to school, too. And there's going to be a funding problem because we're not going to fund -- when they don't open their schools. We're not going to fund them. We're not going to give them money if they're not going to school, if they don't open.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Two points on that. First of all, what the federal government gives is only - is 8 percent.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Ten percent and you know what - that's a lot of money.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And you're going to take - do you know where the money goes? It goes overwhelmingly to disadvantaged kids and children with disabilities.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Let the schools -

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: That (inaudible) spend more money so the schools would be safer.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Chris, let the schools open. Do you ever see the statistics for young people below the age of 18? The state of New Jersey had thousands of deaths. Of all of these thousands, one person below the age of 18 -- in the entire state -- one person and that was a person that had, I believe he said diabetes. One person below the age of 18 died in the state of New Jersey during all of this - you know, they had a hard time. And they're doing very well now, so that's it.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: The stimulus bill is running out at the end of this month.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: The Republicans say they want liability limits, which the Democrats don't like, do say that you want a payroll tax cut, which even some Republicans are cool to.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: But a lot of Republicans like it though.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Will you only sign a bill that has those two provisions?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Well, we're going to see. But we do need protections because businesses are going to get sued just because somebody walked in. Don't know where this virus comes from. They'll sit down at a restaurant. They'll sue the restaurant, the guy's out of business.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: So we do need some kind of immunity. You do need it just like you need immunity for the police, OK, whether they like it or not. You need immunity for the police. But they do need a form of immunity. You don't know if they caught it. And nobody's ever going to be able to prove it one way or the other. Look, the Democrats don't want to do that because they're total - they're totally captured by the lobby of lawyers. The lawyers' lobby is probably the most-

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: - powerful in the country.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: What about the payroll tax cut?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I want to see it. I want to see it.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Is (inaudible) bill?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I'll have to see but yes, I would consider not signing it if we don't have a payroll tax cut. Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Up next, president Trump on the spike in violent crime in America.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: They're Democrat-run cities. They are liberally run. They are stupidly run.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Liberal Democrats have been running cities in this country for decades.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Poorly.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Why is it so bad right now?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And where he stands on a big defense bill that provides for renaming military bases named for Confederate generals.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: This is a bill that funds military operations. It gives soldiers a pay raise.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You're going to veto that?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: More of our exclusive interview with the president when we come back.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Hot enough for you here, Mr. President?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: It's hot. It's about sort of almost record breaking.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You know, we wanted to do it inside. This is your choice.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: But I wanted you to sweat a little bit.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Well, we both are. There has been a spike in violent crime in America in recent weeks. We've seen deaths up in New York, deaths up in Chicago, shootings. How do you explain it, and what are you going to do about it?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I explain it very simply by saying the Democrat-run cities, they are liberally run. They are stupidly run. We have forced them in Seattle to end the CHOP because, you know, we were going in that following day. You probably have heard it. We were getting ready to go in. We were all set. And when they heard that we were going they set their police force.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Liberal Democrats have been running cities in this country for decades.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Poorly.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Why is it so bad right now?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: They run them poorly, it was always bad but now it's gotten totally out of control and it's really because they want to defund the police and Biden wants to defund the police.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Sir, he does not.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Look, he signed a charter with Bernie Sanders; I will get that one just like I was right on the mortality rate. Did you read the charter that he agrees --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: It says nothing about defunding the police.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Oh really? It says abolish, it says defund. Let's go.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Get me the charter, please.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Chris, you've got to start studying for these (ph).

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: He says defund the police?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: He says defund the police, they talk about abolishing the police; they talk about illegal aliens pouring.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I look forward - I look forward to seeing that. The White House has never sent us evidence that Bernie-Biden platform calls for defunding, or abolishing police, because there is none. It calls for increased funding for police departments that meet certain standards. Biden has called for redirecting some police funding for related programs like mental health counseling. This week, you said that Black Lives Matter and the Confederate flag are both matters, issues of freedom of speech.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: But in the case of the Confederate flag, there are a lot of people who say these were traitors who split from this country, fought this country in large part to preserve slavery. Is the Confederate flag offensive?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: It depends on who you're talking about, when you're talking about. When people proudly have their Confederate flags, they're not talking about racism. They love their flag, it represents the South, they like the South. People right now like the South. I'd say it's freedom of many things, but it's freedom of speech.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So you're not offended by it?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Well, I'm not offended either by Black Lives Matter. That's freedom of speech. You know, the whole thing with cancel culture, we can't cancel our whole history. We can't forget that the north and the south fought. We have to remember that, otherwise we'll end up fighting again. You can't -- you can't just cancel all (ph) --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Let me ask you this one. This gets to be more than just cancel -- well, maybe this is cancel culture. The National Defense Authorization Act, the NDAA, you have threatened to veto it because in the bill, and this was supported by Republicans as well as Democrats, that would rename army bases named for Confederate generals. Now, this is a bill that funds military operations, it gives soldiers a pay raise.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You're going to veto that?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: No, because they'll get their pay raise. Hey, look, don't tell me this. I got soldiers the biggest pay raises in the history of our military.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Understood.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I got soldiers brand new equipment, brand new jets, brand new rockets, brand new -- $2.5 trillion. I did more for the military than any president has ever had before me (ph).

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: But you're going to veto this bill (ph)?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Because I think that Fort Gregg, Fort Robert E. Lee, all of these forts that have been named that way for a long time, decades and decades --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: But the military says they're for those.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: - excuse me, excuse me. I don't care what the military says. I do -- I'm supposed to make the decision. Fort Bragg is a big deal. We won two World Wars, nobody even knows General Bragg. We won two World Wars. Go to that community where Fort Bragg is, in a great state, I love that state, go to the community, say how do you like the idea of renaming Fort Bragg, and then what are we going to name it? We're going to name it after the Reverend Al Sharpton? What are you going to name it Chris, tell me what you're going to name it? So there's a whole thing here. We won two World Wars, two World Wars, beautiful World Wars that were vicious and horrible, and we won them out of Fort Bragg, we won them out of all of these forts and now they want to throw those names away. And no, I'm against that, and you know what, most other people are. And I even - I don't believe in polls because I see the fakest polls I've ever seen, but that poll is a 64 percent thing, which actually surprised me. We won World Wars out of these military bases. No, I'm not going to go changing them, I'm not going to go changing them (ph).

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So, you'll veto?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I might. Yes, I might.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: At Mt. Rushmore on July 3rd, you said that we face a far left fascism in this country and then you said this.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: You said our children are taught in school to hate their own country and to believe that the men and women who built it were not heroes but that were villains.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You said our children are taught in school to hate our country. Where do you see that?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I just look at -- I look at school. I watch, I read, look at the stuff. Now they want to change 1492, Columbus discovered America. You know, we grew up, you grew up, we all did, that's what we learned. Now they want to make it the 1619 project. Where did that come from? What does it represent? I don't even know, so --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: It's slavery.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: That's what they're saying, but they don't even know. They just want to make a change. Cancel culture - I hate the term, actually, but I use it

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: But are they (inaudible) hate America.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Yes, I think so. Look at the professors. Look at what's going on in the colleges. If a conservative goes on a college -- and look, we have as many as them. Excuse me, I think to the best of my knowledge, we're sitting at the White House and the Oval Office is right behind me. We have as many as them.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Who's them?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: The liberal radical left, and I'm not talking all -- I think liberal, I could tell you I like a lot of liberal people. I like a lot of liberal governors and senators, but Chris, we have the radical left destructive ideology and it's being taught in our schools. And don't act like you're surprised to hear this -- there are books written about it, and we can't let that go on. We can't let them change the true meaning of what we're all about and that's what they're trying to do; and I don't want it to happen. Not on my watch. It's not going to happen on my watch.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Coming up, President Trump on where the race for the White House stands now. You'll be happy to know that FOX News has a new poll out today and you're going to be the very first person to hear about it.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: We'll discuss that in his opponent Joe Biden when we return with more from the White House.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Coming up, President Trump ways in on his 2020 Democratic rival.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Let me just finish, let me just finish.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I'm going to ask you a direct question about Joe Biden -- is Joe Biden senile?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I don't want to say that. I say he's not competent to be president.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Much more from our exclusive interview after this.

utterances.speaker: CHRIS WALLACE, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.sentences: Mr. President, you'll be happy to know that Fox News has a new poll out today, and you're going to be the very first person to hear about it. In the national horse race, Joe Biden leads you by 8 points, 49 percent to 41. That's, I think, 3, 4 points slimmer than it was --

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: A month ago. And on the issues, people trust Biden more to handle the coronavirus by 17 points, on race relations by 21 points, and even on the economy, they trust Biden more by 1 point. I understand we still have more than a hundred days to this election, but at this point you're losing.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: First of all, I'm not losing because those are fake polls. They were fake in 2016 and now they're even more fake. The polls were much worse in 2016. They interviewed 22 percent Republicans. Well, how do you do 22 percent Republican? You see what's going on. I have other polls that put me (INAUDIBLE). We have polls where I'm leading. I have a poll where we're leading in every swing state. And I don't believe that your -- I -- first of all, the Fox polls, whoever does your Fox polls, they're among the worst. They got it all wrong in 2016. They've been wrong on every poll I've ever seen.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I -- I -- I must tell you --

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: No, I'm just telling you. And -- and let me -- let me ask you this. So, on the economy. So I've always led on the economy by a lot.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I know, which is why I was surprised by this number.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Biden can't put two sentences together. They wheel him out. He goes up. He repeats -- he -- they ask him questions. He reads a teleprompter. And then he goes back into his basement. You tell me the American people want to have that, in an age where we're in trouble with other nations that are looking to do numbers on us.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So let me ask you a direct question.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: No, no, let me just say --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: No, I'm going to ask you a direct question about Joe Biden.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Let me just (INAUDIBLE) --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Is Joe Biden senile?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I don't want to say that. I say he's not competent to be president. To be president, you have to be sharp and tough and so many other things. That -- he doesn't even come out of his basement. They think, oh, this is a great campaign. So he goes in. I'll then make a speech. It will be a great speech. And some young guys start writing, Vice President Biden said this, this, this, this. He didn't say it. Joe doesn't know he's alive, OK? He doesn't know he's alive. Do the American people want that, number one. Number two, I built the greatest economy ever built anywhere in the world, not only in this country, anywhere in the world, until we got hit with the China virus. We got hit with a virus. Shouldn't have happened. And we had to close up. We saved millions of lives. Now we've opened it up. Got to go back to school. We're open. We've got to do things. We had the best job numbers we've ever had last month. We should have good ones coming up in two weeks. Look, I built the greatest economy in history. I'm now doing it again. You see the numbers. The numbers are through the roof.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Right (ph).

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: The Democrats are purposely keeping their schools closed, keeping their states closed. I called Michigan. I want to have a big rally in Michigan. Do you know we're not allowed to have a rally in Michigan? Do you know we're not allowed to have a rally in Minnesota? Do you know we're not allowed to have a rally in Nevada? We're not allowed to have rallies in these Democrat-run states.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Well, some people would say it's -- but, wait a minute, some people would say that it's a health risk, sir.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Some people would say, fine.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: It would -- but, I mean, we -- in -- we had some issues after Tulsa.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: But I -- but I guarantee you, if everything was gone 100 percent, they still wouldn't allow it. They're not allowing me to do it. So they're not -- they're -- they're not allowing me to have rallies.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: But I've got to tell you, I --

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: And I'll do it a different way.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: If I may, sir, respectfully --

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: In the Fox poll, they asked people, who is more competent? Who's got -- who's mind is sounder? Biden beats you in that.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Well, I'll tell you what, let's take a test. Let's take a test right now. Let's go down -- Joe and I will take a test. Let him take the same test that I took (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Incidentally, I took the test too when I heard that you passed it.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Yes, how did you do?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: It's not the hard --- it's not that hardest text.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: No, but the last --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: It isn't -- the picture and it says (INAUDIBLE), and it's an elephant.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: The last -- no, no, (INAUDIBLE) -- you -- you see, that's all misrepresentation.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Well, that's what it was on the web.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: It's all misrepresentation, because, yes, the first few questions are easy. But I'll bet you couldn't even answer the last five questions. I'll bet you couldn't. They get very hard, the last five questions.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Well, one of them was count back from 100 by seven.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: And let me tell you --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Ninety-three.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: You couldn't answer -- you couldn't answer --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: All right, what's a question?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Many of the questions. I'll get you the test. I'd like to give it.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: But I guarantee you that Joe Biden could not answer those questions, OK.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: OK. You talk about --

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: And I answered all 35 questions correctly.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You -- you talk about how you're winning, the campaign's going well. Why did you replace Brad Parscale? Isn't that a --

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Because he's a great digital guy. We all like him a lot. But I have somebody that I -- that was involved. You know, they're all -- they were all on the 2016 campaign.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: And we have Corey and we have all the people. And, actually, Steve Bannon's been much better not being involved. He says the greatest president ever. I mean he's saying things that I said, let's keep Steve out there, he's doing a good job. But they're all being -- they're all involved. If Joe Biden got in, first of all, he won't call the shots. The people -- the radical left people that surround him will call. Religion will be gone, OK? Life, you could forget about that, the whole question of life. Supreme Court --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: When you say life, you mean abortion?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Absolutely. A hundred percent. That whole question, which is a very -- you know, it's always been a 50-50 thing.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I understand.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: It's actually trending a little bit more towards one side now.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: When you say religion is going to be gone, what does that mean?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Well, look at what they're doing to the churches. They won't let the churches even open if they want to stand in a field six feet apart. We've had churches that wanted to stand in fields six feet apart. There has never been an administration that's done so much as I have. From tax cuts, to regulation cuts, to rebuilding the military, to getting choice for the vets. Nobody's done the things I've done. Nobody. In three and a half years, no other president's been able to do what I've done.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You're running, in large part, on the economy. (INAUDIBLE) once. Now we had the coronavirus. You're going to build it again. And, in fact, you had great jobs numbers in May. You had solid jobs numbers in June. But I want you to look at some projections. The non-partisan Congressional Budget Office says the unemployment rate at the end of the year will be 10.5 percent. JPMorgan says in the fourth quarter GDP will contract by 6.2 percent. With states now rolling back some of the reopening and --

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: On purpose.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And -- and -- and -- well, there are a lot of Republicans --

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: On purpose.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: There are a lot of Republican states that are doing it, like Texas.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: There is no reason --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: But here's -- let me just ask --

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: They'll be open very soon.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Let me just ask my question. Isn't there a --

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: There's no reason for California to do -- to be doing what they're doing.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Except for November 3rd.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: With the states shutting back their reopening, in a lot of cases new lockdowns, won't the economy still be a problem for you on Election Day?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I don't think so. I think the economy is expanding and growing beautifully. Now, the Democrats want to keep it closed as long as possible because they think that's good for election. But I think the economy is doing very well. Now we're coming back and we're coming back at a level that nobody would have thought possible. And we are -- and, by the way, take a look at another -- I mean, a gauge, whether you like it or not, the stock market. The stock market, Nasdaq hit its all-time high two weeks ago and has beaten it 14 different times, OK. The stock market, Dow, et cetera, is a thousand points away from its all-time high, meaning very close. We're going to have a stock market perhaps on November 3rd that's the highest in history.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I want to talk to you about Obamacare. Since the pandemic hit, millions of people have lost their jobs and thereby lost their health insurance. And almost a half a million had signed up for Obamacare. Your administration just announced that you're signing on to a lawsuit to overturn Obamacare.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: And replace it.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Why does it make sense to overturn Obamacare, which -- which people now are -- are relying on?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Chris, let me -- because it's no good.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Democrats are going to say, the man who's wanted to kill Obamacare is going to take away your -- the protection for pre-existing conditions.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: First of all, we got rid of the individual mandate.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I understand.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Pre-existing conditions will always be taken care of by me and Republicans, 100 percent.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: But you've been in office three and a half years, you don't have a plan.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Well, we haven't had -- excuse me, you heard me yesterday, we're signing a health care plan within two weeks. A full and complete health care plan that the Supreme Court decision on DACA gave me the right to do. So we're going to solve -- we're going to sign an immigration plan, a health care plan, and various other plans. And nobody will have done what I'm doing in the next four weeks. The Supreme Court gave the president of the United States powers that nobody thought the president had by approving -- by doing what they did, their decision on DACA. And DACA's going to be taken care of also. But we're getting rid of it because we're going to replace it with something much better. But what we got rid of already, which was most of Obamacare, the individual mandate. And that I've already won on. And we won also on the Supreme Court.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: But the decision by the Supreme Court on DACA allows me to do things on immigration, on health care, on other things that we've never done before. And you're going to find it to be a very exciting two weeks.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Up next, we asked the president about those accusations in his niece, Mary Trump's, new book.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Does it hurt you at all to be attacked in such personal terms --

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: By a member of your own family.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And why he's confident he'll end up back in the White House for four more years.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Let Biden sit through an interview like this. He'll be on the ground crying for mommy. He'll say mommy, mommy, please take me home.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: More from the president when we come right back.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Your niece, Mary Trump, has written a book about you and your family. And one of her main points is that she says your dad, Fred Trump Sr., damaged the whole family. And here's what she says about what you learned from your father.

utterances.speaker: MARY TRUMP, PRESIDENT TRUMP'S NIECE
utterances.sentences: He learned to become the killer you mentioned, the man who needs to succeed at all cost, who will do anything to get attention, financial rewards and to win.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Do you see any truth in that?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: My father liked to win. My father was a very good man. He was a strong man. It's disgraceful that she said that. She was not exactly a family favorite. We didn't have a lot of respect or like for her. I would have never said that except she writes a book that's so stupid and so vicious and it's a lie. My father was a great, wonderful man.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: He -- let me just ask you this question.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: And this is not a person that I spent very much time with, very little time. And now I'm glad.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You've developed a pretty thick skin --

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Over the years from decades of attacks in New York tabloids, now from the press here --

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And your political opponents here in Washington. But even for Donald Trump, does it hurt you at all to be attacked in such personal terms.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: By a member of your own family?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: It hurts me more about attacking my father, not being kind to my mother. I have a mother who is like a saint. She was incredible. She was an incredible woman. And she was nasty even to my mother. She's a very scarred person. She was not much of a family person. But, look, let me just tell you, my father was -- I think he was the most solid person I've ever met. And he was a very good person. He was a very, very good person. He was strong, but he was good. For her to say the kind of things, a psychopath, that he was a psychopath. Anybody that knew Fred Trump would call him a psychopath? And, you know what, if he was, I would tell you. And I would say, you know, Chris, I was with my father and it was impossible - my father was - he was tough. He was tough on me. He was tough on all of the kids. But tough in a -- in a solid sense, in a really good sense. For her to say - I think the word she used was psychopath. What a disgrace. She ought to be ashamed of herself. That book is a lie.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Some people were surprised when you agreed to this interview, to sit down with me.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: What are you going to ask?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Especially because of some of the mean tweets that you've said about me. Mike Wallace wannabe. Nasty and obnoxious. I will tell you, after that one, my son, Peter, who you've met, called and he said, nasty, no, obnoxious, maybe.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: But here's the question. One of your beefs seems to be that I put Democrats on the show and I ask them questions. And -- and I guess the question I have is, don't you understand it's my job to put Democrats on as well as Republicans and to ask them probing questions, just like I ask Republicans?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I'm not a big fan of Fox, I'll be honest with you. They've changed a lot since Roger Ailes. And I watch people like Swalwell, who I don't even know, he goes on the show, he got less than 1 percent, all of a sudden he's on - being interviewed for endless (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Yes, but I -- I interviewed Nancy --

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I don't know.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Wait, I interviewed Nancy --

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I watched the nastiest people --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I answer -- I interviewed -- you sent one tweet after I interviewed Nancy Pelosi. And in the interview, I asked her specifically about the fact in February you were in Chinatown pitching tourism while the virus was spreading.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: If the president underplayed the threat in the early days, Speaker Pelosi, didn't you as well?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Isn't that legitimate to talk to the speaker of the House?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I would just say that -- look, I know you very well. I respect you a lot. I respect your father a lot. I thought he was one of the most talented journalists there are. And your, likewise, are a very talented person. I do think this, I think you are a very -- I think you are toward the Democrat side, which is OK. I mean it's OK.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: It's -- it's not true. If -- watch the James Comey interview I did in December.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Seventeen significant errors in the FISA process and you say that it was handled in a thoughtful and appropriate way.

utterances.speaker: JAMES COMEY, FORMER FBI DIRECTOR
utterances.sentences: Yes, he's right, I was wrong.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: But you make it sound like you're a -- a bystander, an eye witness. You were the director of the FBI while a lot of this was going on, sir.

utterances.speaker: COMEY
utterances.sentences: Sure. I'm responsible for the -- that's what I'm telling you, I was wrong. I was over confident as director in our procedures.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You couldn't do as tough an interview with Comey. I -- I'm --

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: OK. OK.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I'd -- I'd like to think I treat everybody the same.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: It just seems to me that you are very prone to be nice to the Democrats. And maybe I'm wrong about that, Chris, but it's an honor to be with you. It's fine. I love it. I love it that it's close to 100 degrees out there.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Your choice again.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Yes, I know, that's OK.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I'm not saying you're going to lose. I am not saying that. We saw how you turned it around last time.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I don't think I'm going to lose at all.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: But if you did, how crushing would it be for you?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: First of all, let me just tell you something. I know everyone wants to know that because they'd love to see me lose finally.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I'm not -- I am not saying that at all. I --

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: You know how many times I've been written off? Do you know how many times I've been written off?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I -- I -- I've done some of it myself, sir.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: My whole life --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I'm not doing it this time.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Don't -- don't do it because that would be bad.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: But how crushing would it be.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: And you know why I won't lose, because the country, in the end ,they're not going to have a man who has - who's shot. He's shot. He's mentally shot. Let him come out of his basement, go around, I'll make four or five speeches a day, I'll be interviewed by you, I'll be interviewed by the worst killers that hate my - my guts. They hate my guts. There's nothing they can ask me that I won't give them a proper answer to. Some people will like it. Some people won't like it.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I agree with that.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: But, look, let --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You answer the questions.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Let Biden sit through an interview like this. He'll be underground crying for mommy. He'll say mommy, mommy, please take me home.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Well, we've asked him for an interview, sir.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: He can't do an interview. He's incompetent. There's a number you don't mention. It's called the enthusiasm number. The enthusiasm for Trump is through the roof, even higher --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I -- I have mentioned it.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Even higher than last time. The enthusiasm for Biden is non- existent. Everyone knows he's shot.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: But the enthusiasm against you is high.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Well, that's OK. That's his only shot.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: And that's his only shot. I agree. And those people know I'm doing a good job. But it's something in my personality that they don't like because, look, nobody's done what I've done. Biden wants to come in and ruin our country, triple your taxes. He wants to do things - he wants to add regulations that I've all cut. And we still have regulation, a lot of regulation, but I've cut it down to a level that nobody's - nobody ever thought possible. He will destroy this country. But it won't be him. It will be the radical left. The same type ideology that took over Venezuela, one of the richest countries in the world. They now have no water, they have no food, and they have no medicine.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Two --

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: That's going to happen here if he wins.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Two final -- two final questions. In general, not talking about November, are you a good loser?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I'm not a good loser. I don't like to lose. I don't lose too often . I don't like to lose.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: But are you gracious?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: You don't know until you see. It depends. I think mail-in voting is -- is going to rig the election. I really do.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Are you suggesting that you might not accept the results of the election?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: No, I have to see. Look, Hillary Clinton asked me the same thing.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: No, I asked you the same thing at the debate.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: No, no, but --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: There is a tradition in this country, in fact one of the prides of this country, is the peaceful transition of power and that no matter how hard fought a campaign is, that at the end of the campaign that the loser concedes to the winner. Not saying that you're necessarily going to be the loser or the winner, but that the loser concedes to the winner and that the country comes together, in part for the good of the country. Are you saying you're not prepared now to commit to that principle?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: What I'm saying is that I will tell you at the time. I'll keep you in suspense, OK?

utterances.speaker: HILLARY CLINTON, FORMER PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.sentences: Well, Chris --

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: And, you know what, she's the one that never accepted it.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I agree.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: She never accepted her loss. And she looks like a fool.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: But can you give a -- can you give a direct answer, you will accept the election?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I have to see. Look, you - I have to see. No, I'm not going to just say yes. I'm not going to say no. And I didn't last time either.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Whether it's in 2021 or 2025, how will you regard your years as President of the United States?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I think I was very unfairly treated. From before I even won, I was under investigation by a bunch of thieves, crooks. It was an illegal investigation. Russia, Russia, Russia.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: But what about the good -- what about the good parts, sir?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: No, no. I want to go this. I have done more than any president in history in the first three and a half years, and I've done it suffering through investigations where people have been -- General Flynn, where people have been so unfairly treated. The Russia hoax, it was all a hoax. The Mueller scam, it was all a scam. It was all false. I made a bad decision on - one bad decision. Jeff Sessions. And now I feel good because he lost overwhelmingly in the great state of Alabama. Here's the bottom line, I've been very unfairly treated. And I don't say that as paranoid. I've been very - everybody says it. It's going to be interesting to see what happens. But there's tremendous evidence right now as to how unfairly treated I was. President Obama and Biden spied on my campaign. It's never happened in history. If it were the other way around, the people would be in jail for 50 years right now. That would be Comey, that would be Brennan, that would be all of this - the two lovers, Strzok and Page, they would be in jail now for many, many years. They would be in jail. It would have started two years ago and they'd be there for 50 years. The fact is, they illegally spied on my campaign. Let's see what happens. Despite that, I did more than any president in history in the first three and a half years.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Mr. President, thank you.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Thanks for talking with us.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Thank you. Thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Up next, remembering an American hero.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: John Lewis, an icon of the civil rights movement, died Friday at age 80. He was the last survivor of the legendary March on Washington in 1963. Five years ago, I sat down with Lewis to discuss his life in the movement he helped lead.

utterances.speaker: REP. JOHN LEWIS (D-GA)
utterances.sentences: They came toward us, beating us with nightsticks, trampling us with the horses. WALLACE (voice over): John Lewis is talking about Bloody Sunday, March 7 1965, when 600 protesters tried to march from Selma to Montgomery, Alabama, to demand their voting rights. It's a key scene in the movie "Selma." John Lewis was the man in the white trench coat. But it's not a movie for Lewis. It's a memory that still burns half a century later.

utterances.speaker: LEWIS
utterances.sentences: I'm trying to protect my head. I really thought I was going to die there.

utterances.speaker: LEWIS
utterances.sentences: The American people saw what happened. They couldn't take it. There was a sense of righteous indignation in America. WALLACE (voice over): On March 15th, President Lyndon Johnson addressed a joint session of Congress and introduced the Voting Rights Act.

utterances.speaker: LYNDON JOHNSON, FORMER U.S. PRESIDENT
utterances.sentences: And we shall overcome.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Lewis was watching on TV, along with Martin Luther King.

utterances.speaker: LEWIS
utterances.sentences: I looked at Dr. King. Tears came down his face. And he said, we will make it from Selma to Montgomery and the Voting Rights Act will be passed. And he was right.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: John Lewis grew up in rural Alabama, went to segregated schools and saw the signs for whites and coloreds. Then he brings up something that happened to his kids in his family when he was 16.

utterances.speaker: LEWIS
utterances.sentences: Trying to get a library card, attempting to check out some books. We were told by the librarian that the library was for whites only and not for colors.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So was voting. By 1965, that was the focus of the civil rights movement. Lewis says Selma selected itself.

utterances.speaker: LEWIS
utterances.sentences: The county was more than 80 percent African-American. (INAUDIBLE) County. There was not a single, registered African-American voter in the county.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Lewis served in Congress for 34 years, but he went back to Selma every year.

utterances.speaker: LEWIS
utterances.sentences: Selma helped free and liberate not just American south, but helped liberate our country.

utterances.speaker: LEWIS
utterances.sentences: As a nation, we've come a great distance. White, colored signs are gone. The only place that we would see those signs today would be in a book, in a museum, or on a video.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: How far do we still have to go?

utterances.speaker: LEWIS
utterances.sentences: We still have a -- a distance to travel before we lay down the burden of race. We're not there yet. But we're on our way. And there will not be any turning back.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Lewis and President Trump at sharp, political differences. The congressman boycotted the Trump inauguration. But, yesterday, the president ordered U.S. flags on all federal buildings lowered to half-staff. And he tweeted he was saddened to hear the news and was sending prayers to Lewis' family. And that's it for this special hour. Have a great week and we'll see you next FOX NEWS SUNDAY. Content and Programming Copyright 2020 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED.
